*   **Who said it?** **Jesus Christ**.
*   **Where is it from?** The **Gospel of Matthew** in the New Testament.
*   **Who wrote it down?** The Apostle **Matthew**.

### No Single Individual Coined the Exact Phrase "Live by the Sword, Die by the Sword"

The well-known saying, "live by the sword, die by the sword," was not coined by a single individual but is a proverbial adaptation of a biblical passage. The sentiment originates from the words of Jesus in the Gospel of Matthew.

The biblical verse, Matthew 26:52, recounts the moment Jesus was arrested in the Garden of Gethsemane. [[1]](https://www.gotquestions.org/live-die-by-the-sword.html) One of his disciples, identified in the Gospel of John as Peter, drew his sword to defend Jesus and cut off the ear of the high priest's servant. [[1]](https://www.gotquestions.org/live-die-by-the-sword.html) Jesus rebuked him, and various translations of the Bible capture his response:

*   **King James Version:** "Then said Jesus unto him, Put up again thy sword into his place: for all they that take the sword shall perish with the sword." [[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Live_by_the_sword,_die_by_the_sword)
*   **New International Version:** "‘Put your sword back in its place,’ Jesus said to him, ‘for all who draw the sword will die by the sword.’” [[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Live_by_the_sword,_die_by_the_sword)
*   **English Standard Version:** "Then Jesus said to him, 'Put your sword back into its place. For all who take the sword will perish by the sword.'" [[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Live_by_the_sword,_die_by_the_sword)

While the core message is consistent, none of these translations use the exact phrasing "live by the sword, die by the sword."

The modern idiom is an evolution of this biblical teaching, which became a common proverb over time, particularly in the medieval period. [[3]](https://sevenswords.uk/common-sayings-swords/) The Latin translation of the sentiment, "Qui gladio ferit, gladio perit" ("He who lives by the sword, dies by the sword"), encapsulates this principle of retributive justice. [[3]](https://sevenswords.uk/common-sayings-swords/)

There have been suggestions that a similar idea appears in the work of the ancient Greek playwright Aeschylus, specifically in his play *Agamemnon*, which deals with themes of cyclical violence and revenge. [[4]](https://www.quora.com/Does-the-phrase-Live-by-the-sword-die-by-the-sword-hold-true)[[5]](https://www.quora.com/Live-by-the-sword-die-by-the-sword-is-a-proverb-in-the-form-of-a-parallel-phrase-which-can-be-traced-back-to-the-ancient-Greek-dramatist-Aeschylus-in-458-BCE-Why-is-it-that-the-saying-appears-in-similar-form-in-the) However, scholars point out that modern translations of Aeschylus sometimes use the familiar English proverb to reflect the theme, rather than Aeschylus having originated the phrase himself. [[5]](https://www.quora.com/Live-by-the-sword-die-by-the-sword-is-a-proverb-in-the-form-of-a-parallel-phrase-which-can-be-traced-back-to-the-ancient-Greek-dramatist-Aeschylus-in-458-BCE-Why-is-it-that-the-saying-appears-in-similar-form-in-the)

In essence, the phrase "live by the sword, die by the sword" is a powerful and concise summary of a principle found in the New Testament, which has been refined through centuries of use in the English language into the idiom we know today.
